ai-sn15:1.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-sn15:1.1.8_0: and craving for sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving.
ai-sn15:1.1.9_0: Suppose a person was to strip all the grass, sticks, branches, and leaves in India, gather them together into one pile, and chop them each into four inch pieces. They’d lay them down, saying:
ai-sn15:1.1.10_0: ‘This is my mother, this is my grandmother.’ The grass, sticks, branches, and leaves of India would run out before that person’s mothers and grandmothers.
ai-sn15:1.1.13_0: and craving for sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving.

ai-sn15:2.1.8_0: and craving for sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving.

ai-sn15:3.1.3_0: and craving for sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving.
ai-sn15:3.1.4_0: What do you think? Which is more: the flow of tears you’ve shed while roaming and transmigrating for such a very long time—weeping and wailing from being united with the unloved and separated from the loved—or the water in the four oceans?”
ai-sn15:3.1.5_0: “As we understand the Buddha’s teaching, the flow of tears we’ve shed while roaming and transmigrating is more than the water in the four oceans.”
ai-sn15:3.2.1_0: “Good, good, mendicants! It’s good that you understand my teaching like this.
ai-sn15:3.2.2_0: The flow of tears you’ve shed while roaming and transmigrating is indeed more than the water in the four oceans.
ai-sn15:3.2.3_0: For a long time you’ve undergone the death of a mother ...
ai-sn15:3.2.4_0: They’ve drunk the flow of tears you’ve shed while roaming and transmigrating is indeed more than the water in the four oceans.
ai-sn15:3.2.5_0: For a long time you’ve undergone the death of a father ...
ai-sn15:3.2.8_0: It’s only because of a child’s flesh ...
ai-sn15:3.2.12_0: or loss through illness. From being united with the unloved and separated from the loved, the flow of tears you’ve shed while roaming and transmigrating is indeed more than the water in the four oceans.
ai-sn15:3.2.15_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:4.1.3_0: and craving for sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving.
ai-sn15:4.1.4_0: What do you think? Which is more: the mother’s milk you’ve drunk while roaming and transmigrating for such a very long time, or the water in the four oceans?”
ai-sn15:4.1.5_0: “As we understand the Buddha’s teaching, the mother’s milk we’ve drunk while roaming and transmigrating is more than the water in the four oceans.”
ai-sn15:4.2.1_0: “Good, good, mendicants! It’s good that you understand my teaching like this.
ai-sn15:4.2.2_0: The mother’s milk you’ve drunk while roaming and transmigrating for such a very long time is more than the water in the four oceans.
ai-sn15:4.2.5_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:5.1.2_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha,
ai-sn15:5.1.5_0: It’s not easy to calculate how many years, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of years it lasts.”
ai-sn15:5.2.1_0: “But sir, can you give a simile?”
ai-sn15:5.2.3_0: “Suppose there was a huge stone mountain, a league long, a league wide, and a league high, with no cracks or holes, one solid mass.
ai-sn15:5.2.4_0: And as each century passed someone would stroke it with a fine cloth from Kāsī.
ai-sn15:5.2.5_0: By this means the huge stone mountain would be worn away before the eon comes to an end.
ai-sn15:5.2.6_0: That’s how long an eon is.
ai-sn15:5.2.7_0: That’s how long an eon is.
ai-sn15:5.2.11_0: This is quite enough for a mendicant to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:6.1.2_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha ... and said to him:
ai-sn15:6.1.5_0: It’s not easy to calculate how many years, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of years it lasts.”
ai-sn15:6.2.1_0: “But sir, can you give a simile?”
ai-sn15:6.2.3_0: “Suppose there was an iron city, a league long, a league wide, and a league high, full of mustard seeds pressed into balls.
ai-sn15:6.2.4_0: And as each century passed someone would remove a single mustard seed.
ai-sn15:6.2.5_0: By this means the huge heap of mustard seeds would be used up before the eon comes to an end.
ai-sn15:6.2.6_0: That’s how long an eon is.
ai-sn15:6.2.7_0: That’s how long an eon is.
ai-sn15:6.2.10_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:7.1.2_0: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn15:7.1.6_0: how many eons of the cosmos there are, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of grains of sand.”
ai-sn15:7.2.1_0: “But sir, can you give a simile?”
ai-sn15:7.2.3_0: “Suppose there were four disciples with a lifespan of a hundred years.
ai-sn15:7.2.4_0: And each day they would each recollect a hundred thousand eons.
ai-sn15:7.2.5_0: Those four disciples would pass away after a hundred years and there would still be eons that they haven’t recollected.
ai-sn15:7.2.6_0: That’s how many eons have passed.
ai-sn15:7.2.8_0: how many eons of the eons or how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of grains of sand.
ai-sn15:7.2.11_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:8.1.1_0: Near Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove ...
ai-sn15:8.1.2_0: Then a certain brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
ai-sn15:8.1.3_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
ai-sn15:8.1.3_1: Seated to one side he said to the Buddha:
ai-sn15:8.1.7_0: how many eons of the cosmos there are, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of grains of sand.”
ai-sn15:8.2.1_0: “But sir, can you give a simile?”
ai-sn15:8.2.3_0: “Consider the Ganges river from where it originates to where it enters the ocean. Between these places it’s not easy to calculate
ai-sn15:8.2.4_0: how many grains of sand there are, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of grains of sand.
ai-sn15:8.2.5_0: The eons that have passed are more than this.
ai-sn15:8.2.7_0: how many eons of the eons or how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of grains of sand.
ai-sn15:8.2.10_0: and craving for sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving.
ai-sn15:8.2.11_0: For such a long time you have undergone suffering, agony, and disaster, swelling the cemeteries.
ai-sn15:8.2.12_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:8.3.1_0: The brahmin said to the Buddha,
ai-sn15:8.3.3_0: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-sn15:9.1.3_0: and craving for sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving.
ai-sn15:9.1.4_0: Suppose a stick was tossed up in the air. Sometimes it’d fall on its bottom, sometimes the middle, and sometimes the top.
ai-sn15:9.1.5_0: In the same way, ignorance and fettered by craving, sentient beings wander and transmigrates to their own fools, and they make others return to this world.
ai-sn15:9.1.8_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:10.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
ai-sn15:10.2.2_0: One person roaming and transmigrating for an eon would amass a heap of bones the size of this Mount Vepulla, if they were gathered together and not lost.
ai-sn15:10.2.5_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:10.3.1_0: This is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn15:10.3.2_0: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

ai-sn15:10.7.4_0: with the ending of all fetters.
ai-sn15:10.8.4_0: and the rod with a person.
ai-sn15:11.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī.
ai-sn15:11.1.2_0: There they stayed here and there.
ai-sn15:11.1.4_0: and craving for sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving.
ai-sn15:11.1.5_0: When you see someone in a sorry state, in distress, you should conclude:
ai-sn15:11.1.7_0: Why is that? Transmigration has no known beginning. ...
ai-sn15:11.1.8_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:11.1.9_0: First the first part of the body.
ai-sn15:12.1.3_0: When you see someone in a good way, in a happy state, you should conclude:
ai-sn15:12.1.7_0: The border of the tank was not found.
ai-sn15:12.1.8_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:13.1.1_0: Near Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove ...
ai-sn15:13.1.2_0: Then thirty mendicants from Pāvā went to the Buddha. All of them lived in the wilderness, ate only alms-food, wore rag robes, and owned just three robes; yet they all still have fetters.
ai-sn15:13.1.2_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-sn15:13.1.3_0: Then it occurred to the Buddha:
ai-sn15:13.1.4_0: “These thirty mendicants from Pāvā live in the wilderness, eat only alms-food, wear rag robes, and own just three robes; yet they all still have fetters.
ai-sn15:13.1.5_0: Why don’t I teach them the Dhamma in such a way that their minds are freed from defilements by not grasping while sitting in this very seat?”
ai-sn15:13.1.6_0: The Buddha said to the mendicants,
ai-sn15:13.2.2_0: and craving for sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving.
ai-sn15:13.2.3_0: What do you think? Which is more: the flow of blood you’ve shed when your head was chopped off while roaming and transmigrating for such a very long time, or the water in the four oceans?”
ai-sn15:13.2.4_0: “As we understand the Buddha’s teaching, the flow of blood you’ve shed when your head was chopped off while roaming and transmigrating is more than the water in the four oceans.”
ai-sn15:13.3.1_0: “Good, good, mendicants! It’s good that you understand my teaching like this.
ai-sn15:13.3.2_0: The flow of blood you’ve shed when your head was chopped off while roaming and transmigrating is indeed more than the water in the four oceans.
ai-sn15:13.3.3_0: For a long time you’ve been cows, and the flow of blood you’ve shed when your head was chopped off as a cow is more than the water in the four oceans.
ai-sn15:13.3.4_0: For a long time you’ve been buffalo ...
ai-sn15:13.3.5_0: For a long time you’ve been buffalo ...
ai-sn15:13.3.10_0: For a long time you’ve been bandits, arrested for raiding villages,
ai-sn15:13.3.12_0: or adultery. And the flow of blood you’ve shed when your head was chopped off as a bandit is more than the water in the four oceans.
ai-sn15:13.3.15_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:13.4.1_0: This is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn15:13.4.2_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-sn15:13.4.3_0: And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of the thirty mendicants from Pāvā were freed from defilements by not grasping.
ai-sn15:14.1.3_0: It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your mother.
ai-sn15:14.1.6_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:15.1.3_0: It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your father. ...
ai-sn15:15.1.4_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:16.1.2_0: “It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your brother. ...
ai-sn15:16.1.3_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:17.1.2_0: “It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your sister. ...
ai-sn15:17.1.3_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:18.1.2_0: “It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your son. ...
ai-sn15:18.1.3_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

ai-sn15:19.1.4_0: It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your daughter.
ai-sn15:19.1.7_0: and craving for sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving.
ai-sn15:19.1.8_0: For a long time you’ve undergone suffering, agony, and disaster, swelling the cemeteries.
ai-sn15:19.1.9_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:20.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
ai-sn15:20.2.2_0: and craving for sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving.
ai-sn15:20.2.3_0: Once upon a time, mendicants, this Mount Vepulla was known as Pācīnavaṁsa.
ai-sn15:20.2.4_0: And at that time people were known as Tivaras.
ai-sn15:20.2.5_0: The lifespan of the Tivaras was 40,000 years.
ai-sn15:20.2.6_0: It took them four days to climb Mount Vepulla, and four days to descend.
ai-sn15:20.2.7_0: At that time Kakusandha, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha arose in the world.
ai-sn15:20.2.8_0: Kakusandha had a fine pair of chief disciples named Vidhura and Sañjīva.
ai-sn15:20.2.9_0: But see that mountain’s in Sāgata, the people of Sāgata passed away, and the Buddha became fully extinguished.
ai-sn15:20.2.13_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.
ai-sn15:20.3.1_0: Once upon a time this Mount Vepulla was known as Vaṅkaka.
ai-sn15:20.3.2_0: And at that time people were known as Rohitassas.
ai-sn15:20.3.3_0: The lifespan of the Rohitassas was 30,000 years.
ai-sn15:20.3.4_0: It took them three days to climb Mount Vepulla, and three days to descend.
ai-sn15:20.3.5_0: At that time Koṇāgamana, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha arose in the world.
ai-sn15:20.3.6_0: Koṇāgamana had a fine pair of chief disciples named Koṇāgamana.
ai-sn15:20.3.7_0: But see that mountain’s in Sāgata, the people of Sāgata passed away, and the Buddha became fully extinguished.
ai-sn15:20.3.9_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.
ai-sn15:20.4.1_0: Once upon a time this Mount Vepulla was known as Supassa.
ai-sn15:20.4.2_0: And at that time people were known as Suppiyas.
ai-sn15:20.4.3_0: The lifespan of the Suppiyas was 20,000 years.
ai-sn15:20.4.4_0: It took them two days to climb Mount Vepulla, and two days to descend.
ai-sn15:20.4.5_0: At that time Kassapa, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha arose in the world.
ai-sn15:20.4.6_0: Kassapa had a fine pair of chief disciples named Tissa.
ai-sn15:20.4.7_0: But see that mountain’s in Sāgata, the people of Sāgata passed away, and the Buddha became fully extinguished.
ai-sn15:20.4.10_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.
ai-sn15:20.5.1_0: These days this Mount Vepulla is known as Vepulla.
ai-sn15:20.5.2_0: And these people are known as Magadhans.
ai-sn15:20.5.3_0: The lifespan of the Magadhans is short, brief, and fleeting.
ai-sn15:20.5.4_0: A long life is a hundred years or a little more.
ai-sn15:20.5.5_0: It takes the Magadhans an hour to climb Mount Vepulla, and an hour to descend.
ai-sn15:20.5.6_0: And now I am the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha who has arisen in the world.
ai-sn15:20.5.7_0: I have a fine pair of chief disciples named Sāriputta and Moggallāna.
ai-sn15:20.5.8_0: There will come a time when this mountain’s name will vanish, those people will die, and I will be fully extinguished.
ai-sn15:20.5.12_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
ai-sn15:20.6.1_0: This is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn15:20.6.2_0: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
ai-sn15:20.8.1_0: All conditions are impermanent and unlikeable,
ai-sn15:20.9.5_0: The Linked Discourses on the unknown beginning are complete.
